resources.string: Custom drawer implementation for Material design apps.\n\nMade by Heinrich Reimer

Example of using DrawerFrameLayout for the drawer.
This drawer has a custom max width of 250dp.

Check out the sample code on GitHub!

Example of using DrawerActivity for the drawer.
This drawer shows theming and has a custom Toolbar set.

Very simple ;)

html.p:
Age 2-5 yrs: initially 35 micrograms/kg in 3 divided doses for 24 hrs then 10 micrograms/kg daily in 1–2 doses
Age 5-10 yrs: initially 25 micrograms/kg (max. 750 micrograms) in 3 divided doses for 24 hours then 6 micrograms/kg daily (max. 250 micrograms daily) in 1–2 doses
Age 10–18 yrs: initially 0.75–1.5 mg in 3 divided doses for 24 hrs then 62.5–250 micrograms daily in 1–2 doses

string-array.name: resc
string-array.item: Infact Child with Signs of Life

resources.string:
Adrenaline

1 in 10,000 : Give 0.1ml/kg in resuscitation.

To make this strength dilute 1 ml of 1 in 1000 adrenaline in 9 mls water for injection to make 10mls

For severe viral croup 0.5 ml/kg of 1:1000 solution (max dose:5 ml)

Amikacin

Age 1month to 12 yrs,15mg/kg once daily.

Same dosing can be used in newborns. Slow iv over 3-5 min

Amikacin trough concentration should be monitored ( if available)

If serious gram - ve infection / resistance to gentamicin, higher doses may be used with monitoring

Aminophylline(iv)

ONLY used in hospital inpatients!

Newborn Loading dose 6mg/kg iv over 1 hour or rectal,

Maintenance (iv or oral) : Age 0 ≤ 6 days - 2.5mg/kg 12hrly, Age 7-28 days - 4mg/kg 12hrly.

Asthma: 5mg/kg iv first dose over 30 mins Max 500mg

Amoxicillin

Age >7days: Use 25mg/kg/dose 12 hourly for simple infections and 40-45mg/kg 12 hourly for pneumonia /p>

Newborns: 25mg/kg 12hourly,

Ampicillin

Neonate: 50mg/kg/dose 12 hourly iv or im if aged < 7 days and 8 hourly if aged 8 - 28 days.

Age 1m and over: 50mg/kg/dose (Max 500mg) 8 hourly

Artesunate

3mg/kg At 0,12, and 24h then daily for max 7 days

If weight >20Kg give 2.4mg/kg/dose

Given iv / im for a minimum of 24 hours

As soon as the child can eat drink (after 24 hours for artesunate) then change to a full course of artemisinin

combination therapy (ACT) typically the 1st line oral anti-malarial, Artemether Lumefantrine.

Beclomethasone

Age < 2yrs 50-100 micrograms 12 hrly,

Age ≥ 2yrs 100-200 micrograms 12 hrly.

Can double doses to improve control but check

technique and follow up carefully

Benzyl Penicillin (X-pen)

Age < 6days: 50,000 iu/kg/dose 12 hourly iv or im.

Age 7 days and over: 50,000 iu/kg/dose 6 hourly iv / im

Double Penicillin doses when treating meningitis and age >1 month.

Caffeine Citrate

Loading dose: oral: 20 mg/kg (or iV over 30 min) maintenance dose: 5 mg/kg daily oral (or iV over 30 min)

Carbamazepine

Age 1 m - 12 yrs: initially 5 mg/kg at night, increased as necessary by 2.5 - 5 mg/kg every 3 -7 days;

Usual maintenance dose 5 mg/kg 2-3 times daily.

Avoid abrupt withdrawal and watch carefully for side effects

Cefotaxime

Preferred to Ceftriaxone for treatment of neonatal meningitis if aged < 7 days:

Pre-term: 50mg/kg 12 hourly;

Term aged < 7 days: 50mg/kg 8 hourly

Calcium

Monitor calcium especially if on Vitamin D or long term therapy

Severe hypocalcemia

V bolus of 10% calcium gluconate 0.5 ml/kg (0.11 mmol/kg) to a maximum of 20 ml/kg over 5 – 10 min then continuous IV infusion

over 24 h of 1.0 mmol/kg (maximum 8.8 mmol).

Mild hypocalcemia

Oral calcium 0.2 mmol/kg to a maximum of 10 mmol 6 hourly

Ceftriaxone

Neonates: Not recommended if Jaundiced or <7days.

Max 50mg/kg 24hourly

7 days: Meningitis or Very severe sepsis 50mg/kg 12 hourly not to exceed 4g/day

Ciprofloxacin(oral)

Dysentery dosing: 15mg/kg/dose 12 hourly for 3 days

Note: may increase renal toxicity of gentamicin/amikacin

Clotrimazole 1%

Use Clotrimazole paint for oral thrush and apply 2-3 times daily until cleared

Co-trimoxazole

Co-trimoxazole pneumonia dozing 4mg/kg trimethoprim and 20mg/kg sulphamethoxazole

" + "\n" + "\n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + " \n" + "
Weight240mg/5ml (syrup)\n" + "12 hrly480mg (tabs)\n" + "12 hrly
2 - 3kg 2.5 mls 1/4
4 - 10kg \n5 mls 1/2
11 - 15 kg 7.5 mls 1/2
16 - 20 kg 10 mls 1

Dexamethasone

IV or IM 0.6mg/kg stat for severe croup

Dextrose/glucose

5mls/kg 10%% dextrose iv over 3-5 mins

Neonate : 2 mls/kg

TO MAKE 10%% dextrose using 50%%dextrose and water for injection: 10 mls syringe; 2mls 50%% dextrose + 8mls

water. 20mls Syringe; 4mls 50%% dextrose + 16mls water.

TO MAKE 10%% dextrose using 50%%dextrose and 5% dextrose: 10 mls syringe; 1mls 50%% dextrose + 9mls water.

20mls Syringe; 2mls 50%% dextrose + 18mls water.

Ceftazidime

1 mo-12 yrs : 30-50 mg/kg IM/IV 8 hourly (Max: 6 g/day)

Age < 7 days or weight < 1200g : 50 mg/kg IM/IV 12 hourly

Age > 7 days or weight >1200 g : 50 mg/kg IM/IV 8 hourly

Dihydrocodeine

Age 1- 4 yrs:

0.5mg / kg every 4-6 hours

Age 4 - 12 yrs :

0.5 -1 mg/kg (max. 30 mg) every 4 - 6 hrs

Diazepam (rectal)

0.5mg/kg

The whole syringe barrel of a 1ml or 2ml syringe should be inserted gently so that the pr dose is given at a depth of 4-5cm

Digoxin (oral)

Age 2-5 yrs: initially 35 micrograms/kg in 3 divided doses for 24 hrs then 10 micrograms/kg daily in 1 - 2 doses

Age 5-10 yrs: initially 25 micrograms/kg (max 750 micrograms) in 3 divided doses for 24 hours then 6

micrograms/kg daily (max.250 micrograms daily) in 1-2 doses

Age 10-12 yrs : initially 0.75-1.5 mg in 3 divided doses for 24 hrs then 62.5-250 micrograms daily in 1-2 doses

Erythromycin

30-50 mg/kg/day in 3-4 divided doses; max: 2 g/day

Flucloxacillin

Neonates: 50mg/kg iv/im 12hourly

25mg/kg po 12 hourly

>7days: 50mg/kg iv/im 8 hourly

15mg/kg po 8 hourly

Gentamicin

7.5 mg/kg/24 hr

Gentamicin used OD should be given im or as a slow iv push over 2-3 minutes

If a baby is not obvioulsy passing urine after more than 24 hours, consider stopping the Gentamicin

Hydroxyurea

(For severe SCD only: Pain >3 episodes/ yr; stroke; transfusion ≥ 2/ yr; acute chest syndrome)

Child 2-12 years initially 10-15mg/kg once daily, increased every 12 weeks in steps of 2.5 - 5 mg/kg daily according

to response; usual dose 15 - 30 mg/kg daily (max. 35 mg/kg)

Iron (Fe)

Iron deficiency anaemia: Pre-term infant: 2 - 4 mg elemental Fe/kg/day max dose: 15 mg elemental Fe/day

Child: 3 - 6 mg elemental Fe/kg/day

Prophylaxis: Pre-term infant 2 - 4 mg elemental Fe/kg/24 hr max dose: 15 mg elemental Fe/day

Term: 1-2mg elemental Fe/24 hr Max 15mg per day

Lactulose

Hepatic Encephalopathy Infants: 1.7 - 6.7 g/day (2.5 - 10 mL) orally daily divided in 3 to 4 doses.

Adjust dosage to produce 2 - 3 soft stools per day

Children: 25-60 g/day <(40-90 mL) orally daily divided in 3-4 doses.

Adjust dosage to produce 2-3 soft stools/day

Chronic constipation: Children: 0.7 - 2 gm/kg/day (1 to 3 mL/kg/day) orally in divided doses daily; not to exceed

40 g/day (60 mL/day)

Mebendazole

(for age>1yr) 100mg bd for 3 days or 500mg stat

Morphine

Neonate: 0.05 - 0.2 mg/kg/dose IM, SC, slow IV every 4hr

Infant and Child: PO 0.2 - 0.5 mg/kg/dose every 4 - 6 hr as needed

IM IV/SC 0.1 - 0.2 mg/kg/dose every 2-4 hrs as needed max 15 mg/dose

Nystatin

Pre terms 0.5ml (50,000 U) to each side of the mouth 6 hourly(2 weeks if HIV +ve)

Terms 1ml (100,000 U) to each side of the mouth 6hrly (2 weeks if HIV+ve)

Phenobarbitone

Loading with 15mg/kg (if NOT on maintenance phenobarb)

followed by 2.5mg - 5mg/kg daily,

Convulsions in the first 1 month of life should be treated with Phenobarbitone 20mg/kg stat, a further 5-10mg/kg can be given within 24 hours of the loading dose with maintenance doses of 5mg/kg daily

Phenytoin

Age 1m - 12 yrs ( IV, oral) 15-20 mg/kg at a rate not exceeding 1 mg/kg/minute as a loading dose

maintenance dose of 2.5 - 5 mg/kg twice daily (max. 150mg twice daily)

Similar dosing can be used in neonates.

Prednisolone - tabs

Asthma 2mg / kg daily(usually for 3-5 days, stopped when symptoms largely resolved)

Valproate(sodium)

Neonate initially 20mg/kg once daily; maintenance 10 mg/kg twice daily PO

1 mo - 12yrs initially 10-15 mg/kg (max. 600mg) daily in 1-2 divided doses max 60 mg/kg daily.

Maintenance 25-30 mg/kg daily in 2 divided doses PO

Vitamin A

Once on admission,not to be repeated within 1 month. For malnutrition with eye disease repeat on day 2 and day 14

Age , Dosage Oral < 6m , 50,000 u stat 6 - 12m , 100,000 u stat > 12m , 200,000 u stat

Vitamin D - Chole or ergocalciferol:

Rickets: Low dose regimens daily for 8-12wks or one high dose. ± Calcium for first week of treatment.

Age , Dosage Oral < 6m , 3,000 u = 75 micrograms > 6m , 6,000 u = 150 micrograms > 6m stat im regimen , 300,000 u = 7.5 mg Stat

Vitamin D – Maintenance After treatment course

Age , Dosage Oral 6 - 12m , 200 - 400 u (5 – 10μg) < 6m , 400 - 800 u (10 – 20μg)

Vitamin K

Newborns: 1mg stat im (<1500g, 0.5mg im stat)

For liver disease: 0.3mg/kg stat, max 10mg

Zinc Sulphate

Age ≤ 6m: 10mg daily for 14 days

Age > 6 m: 20mg daily for 14 days

Quinine

Loading 20mg/kg iv/im then 10mg/kg 8 hourly

Do not give more than 3mls per injection site.(IM)

Salbutamol

IV therapy should only be used on an HDU, ideally with a monitor, and MUST be given slowly as directed

Oral salbutamol should ONLY be used if it is the only option available

IV in hospital only over 5 mins - < 2 yrs 5 microgram/kg, ≥ 2 yrs up to 15 microgram/kg max dose 250 micrograms(0.25mg

Nebulised: 2.5mg/dose as required

Inhaled (Acute exacerbation) (100 microgram per puff) 2 puffs via spacer repeated as required acutely or 2 puffs up to 4-6 hrly for acute wheeze for < 5 days

Oral (no longer recommended unless no inhaled therapy

Age 2-12yrs 1-2mg/dose 6 - 8hrly

(1 week only-not suitable for maintenance therapy)
